clinical_study.brief_title: Comprehensibility of Colorectal Cancer Screening Educational Materials: Effects on Patient Knowledge and Motivation
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Comprehensibility of Colorectal Cancer Screening Educational Materials on Patient Knowledge and Motivation: A Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether a newly developed patient education document concerning colorectal cancer screening will be better understood and have greater effects on patient knowledge of and motivation for screening than a standard educational document.

primary_outcome.measure: Comprehension of randomly assigned educational document
primary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after receiving randomly assigned study intervention (that same day)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after receiving randomly assigned study intervention (that same day)

secondary_outcome.measure: Self-efficacy for undergoing colorectal cancer screening
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after receiving randomly assigned study intervention (that same day)

secondary_outcome.measure: Perceived barriers to undergoing colorectal cancer screening
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after receiving randomly assigned study intervention (that same day)

secondary_outcome.measure: Readiness to undergo colorectal cancer screening
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after receiving randomly assigned study intervention (that same day)

intervention.intervention_name: New colorectal cancer screening patient education document
intervention.description: The newly developed educational document was created accounting for health behavioral models (such as the Expanded Health Behavior Model, Social Cognitive Theory, and the Transtheoretical Model) and related research studies indicating the factors that most strongly and positively influence patients' cognitions regarding colorectal cancer screening and are, in turn, predictive of actual colorectal cancer screening behavior.

intervention.intervention_name: Traditional colorectal cancer screening education document
intervention.description: The traditional educational document is a slightly edited version of materials freely available on the National Cancer Institute (NCI) web site, used in this study with the permission of the NCI.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Receive primary care at one of the participating outpatient offices
- Age 50-75
- Able to read and speak English
- Adequate vision, hearing, and hand function to read printed documents, communicate with research staff, answer questionnaires, and otherwise participate
- Not up to date for colorectal cancer screening (defined as fecal occult blood test within 1 year, flexible sigmoidoscopy within 5 years, or colonoscopy within 10 years)
